sourceDesc.p: Replaces Extract in Pilgrim Letters 12, p. 117. | Text from facsimile in Swann Auction Galleries online catalogue, May 2016.

body.p: I cannot tell you how truly I feel your kind remembrance of your friend undersigned, or what delightful associations I shall always connect with the beautiful cigar case before me at this present writing. – Thank you! –

Since I came backFor W.H. Wills’s incapacitation after a fall from a horse see To Alfred Dickens, 16 May 1868, Pilgrim Letters 12, p. 111., I have been so overwhelmed by six months of arrears of business, intensely complicated by the illness of Wills,3 that I have been constantly afflicted with a revolving nightmare. I hope however to send round “The Duke’s Motto”Originally The Duke's Daughter; or The Hunchback of Paris, adapted by John Brougham, first performed in England at the Lyceum, 1 Oct 63, with Charles Fechter as the hero; performed as The Duke's Motto in the Grecian Saloon, 18 Jan 64. Perhaps sent for review, but no notice of it appeared in Kent's Sun., this next week. I have been here – there – everywhere – and (most of all) nowhere – from the time of my re-beholding Euston Square.5

closer.salute: Ever my Dear Kent |Your truly affectionate Friend
